title: SHIP Medicare-Only Q1: Timing for Initial Medicare Enrollment and Subsequent Changes
description: SHIP mystery-shopper study Question #1 from Medicare-Only scenario (eAppendix 1). Tests knowledge of when to enroll in Medicare and when coverage changes can be made.
source: Dugan K et al. JAMA Network Open. 2025;8(4):e252834 - eAppendix 1, Question #1; eAppendix 4

persona.current_coverage: Employer-based health coverage with prescription drug coverage
persona.situation: Turning 65 in 2 months, just becoming eligible for Medicare (aging in). Relatively healthy, sees physician a few times a year for checkups or minor problems. Takes Lipitor 10mg daily for cholesterol. Not on Medicaid and does not qualify for it. Has received Medicare card but doesn't have it readily available.

scripted_turns.user_message: When can I enroll in Medicare and select my coverage? And when can I make changes to my coverage after I've enrolled?
expected_topics: Initial enrollment period - within 3 months of turning 65
Annual Election Period (AEP) - October 15 to December 7
Open Enrollment Period (OEP) - January 1 to March 31

canonical_facts.statement: You can enroll in Medicare and select coverage within 3 months of turning 65 years of age (the 7-month initial enrollment period: 3 months before, month of, and 3 months after your 65th birthday).

After initial enrollment, you can make changes during the Annual Election Period (AEP, October 15 - December 7 each year), Open Enrollment Period (OEP), or Special Enrollment Periods (SEP) when you have a qualifying life event.
The Annual Election Period (October 15 to December 7) is when most people can switch Medicare Advantage plans, switch Part D plans, or switch between Original Medicare and Medicare Advantage.
Special Enrollment Periods allow you to make changes outside the regular enrollment periods if you have a qualifying life event (e.g., moving, losing coverage, gaining Medicaid).

disallowed_claims: Stating you must enroll at exactly 65 without mentioning the 7-month window
Claiming there is no way to change plans after initial enrollment
Providing incorrect dates for AEP or other enrollment periods
acceptable_referrals: Social Security Administration for Part A/B enrollment
State Health Insurance Assistance Program (SHIP) for local counseling

score_1.label: Accurate and Complete
score_1.criteria: Response substantively covers BOTH: (1) Initial enrollment within 3 months of turning 65, AND (2) When changes can be made (AEP, OEP, or SEP)

score_2.label: Substantive but Incomplete
score_2.criteria: Response substantively covers ONE but not both components

score_3.label: Not Substantive
score_3.criteria: Response does not substantively address either component

score_4.label: Incorrect
score_4.criteria: Incorrect information that could materially affect enrollment decisions

temporal_validity.notes: Based on SHIP mystery-shopper study (Dugan et al. 2025).
